dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.rights: ©1995-2013, The Regents of the University of Michigan and its licensors
dataObjects.rightsHolder: The Regents of the University of Michigan and its licensors
dataObjects.bibliographicCitation: Baranowski, C. 2011. "Palaemonetes paludosus" (On-line), Animal Diversity Web. Accessed April 27, 2013 at http://animaldiversity.ummz.umich.edu/site/accounts/information/Palaemonetes_paludosus.html
dataObjects.description:
Palaemonetes paludosus, commonly known as glass shrimp, eastern grass shrimp, or ghost shrimp, is naturally found in freshwater ponds, lakes, and streams in the coastal plain of North American east of the Allegheny Mountains, from Florida to New Jersey. The California Department of Fish and Game introduced Palaemonetes paludosus in the lower Colorado River, it is now established in various locations in California. It is also found in Louisiana, Texas, and Oklahoma, where it has most likely been introduced.

Biogeographic Regions: nearctic (Introduced , Native )

agents.full_name: Keith Pecor, The College of New Jersey
Chelsea Baranowski, The College of New Jersey
Tanya Dewey, University of Michigan-Ann Arbor

dataObjects.title: National Distribution
dataObjects.description:
United States

Origin: Native

Regularity: Regularly occurring

Currently: Present

Confidence: Confident

Type of Residency: Year-round

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Global Range: (200,000-2,500,000 square km (about 80,000-1,000,000 square miles)) Native to U.S. coastal plain from Florida to New Jersey as well as Gulf states, but introduced elsewhere in U.S. (Wu and Brown, 1980).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description:
Number of teeth of dactylus: 0/0
Rostral teeth: 6-8 on dorsal surface; tip naked; 3-4 on ventral surface
Upper antennular flagellum: fused part of the two rami longer than free part
Poistion of branchiostegal spine: on anteroventral part of branchiostegal groove
Approximate maximum total length (mm): 47
Number, size, and color of eggs: few, large, usually greenish

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat
dataObjects.description: Comments: Freshwater member of the genus but often lives in brackish waters (Anderson, 1985).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Habitat

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Migration
dataObjects.description:
Non-Migrant: No. All populations of this species make significant seasonal migrations.

Locally Migrant: No. No populations of this species make local extended movements (generally less than 200 km) at particular times of the year (e.g., to breeding or wintering grounds, to hibernation sites).

Locally Migrant: No. No populations of this species make annual migrations of over 200 km.

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Reproduction
dataObjects.description: For more repoductive information, see Anderson (1985). Spawns all year in southern Florida.
